By SHAEL GOLDMACHER

Donald J. Trump's lead in the 2024 presidential race has widened after President Biden's handling. Other performance that week, an economy that Mr. Biden took to deal to govern effectively rose to new highs among Democratic and independent voters, a new poll from The New York Times and Simon College showed.

Mr. Trump won a lead. Mr. Biden ran for president in a recent anyway likely voters nationally, a 13-point swing toward the Republican from just a week earlier, before the debate. It is the largest lead Mr. Trump has recorded in a Times/Siena poll since 2015. Mr. Trump leads by even more among registered voters, 61 percent to 40 percent.

Doubts about Mr. Biden's age and seniority and widespread growing, A majority of every demographic group, regardless of age and background, is more likely to say they will vote for him than for Mr. Biden, and it is too small to tell whether the difference is real or not.

Overall, 71 percent of voters who said they would vote for Mr. Biden in a poll are in the 60s, up from 58 percent in the 2016 election. Mr. Biden's age has waned slightly, but the gap between the two groups has widened.
